Rockwood will resume distributing free "Grab-N-Go" breakfast and lunch meals for community members aged 1-18 on Monday, Sept. 14.

LaSalle Springs Middle science teacher Sarah Harashe turned her school grounds into a lab to conduct an experiment about speed, velocity and acceleration Sept. 2.

Harashe’s eighth-grade class participated in the lesson via a Zoom video conference.

“The lab went quite well. I pre-marked 100 feet of road with orange cones outside," Harashe said. “I logged in to Zoom on my phone, and I became the speaker of our outdoor meeting."

The goal of the lesson was to obtain real-time data in order to calculate the velocity of vehicles traveling northbound and southbound on Highway 109.

While Rockwood students are returning to school online the week of Aug. 24, Rockwood school bus drivers will be out on roads in the district training.

Drivers will begin training that includes classroom instruction and time in the driver's seat.

Rockwood has 191 school buses. Transportation Director Mike Heyman said officials will only be training about 35 drivers at a time, so they can maintain social distancing during the classroom portion.

"Our school bus drivers need to keep their skills sharp," said Heyman. "Drivers have not been behind the wheel since March, and they need to practice safe driving techniques so that when in-person school does resume, students can be transported in as safe a manner as possible."

- five days per week of at-home education through online curriculum

Rockwood administrators and activities directors are working to allow students and staff to return to activities/athletics in a safe environment during the first half of July.

In doing so, they are following the guidelines established by sports medicine and pediatric infectious disease professionals in the St. Louis area.

SSM Health, BJC HealthCare and Mercy have collaborated to provide recommendations related to the re-socialization of both youth and high school sports in the St. Louis region during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The guidelines are as follows:

- students complete COVID symptom screeners each day before arriving on campus.

- the number of students will be limited per venue (location) on campus.

- participants will arrive dressed for their activity and bring their own water. Locker room facilities will not be available.

- parent drop-off/pick-up only; no spectators.

- regular hand sanitizing; frequent wiping of equipment during and after use.

- focus will be on individual skill drills/conditioning work; no "contact" during this phase.

Tuesday night was Eureka High's turn to celebrate the Class of 2020 with its POWERplex STL graduation ceremony. Spectators cheered - and honked their horns - for the graduates as they received their diplomas and began the next chapter in their lives.

"We are extremely proud of all you have accomplished – in academics, in the arts and in athletics," Superintendent Dr. Mark Miles said in his address to the students. "These myriad accomplishments have been celebrated throughout your tenure in our schools."

A group of seven Eureka students sang The Star-Spangled Banner at the beginning of the ceremony, and graduates Julia Collins, Avery Hanson and Ethan Fine addressed their fellow students during the festivities.

"Whatever it is you decide to do, you are far more equipped than you may feel," Fine said. "Think of all you have learned at EHS. Sure, you read some books, made some flashcards, probably bought a highly priced calculator. But I'm talking about values. At EHS, we learned to be kind, empathetic, passionate and determined."

Congratulations, Class of 2020!

Congratulations to Rockwood School District Teacher of the Year Dr. Cathy Farrar!

Farrar has taught science at Marquette High since 2012. She earned her bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Missouri – St. Louis.

“I’m surrounded by great educators, so it’s really awesome to be recognized,” said Farrar. “It’s an honor to be in the Rockwood school community.”

Farrar fosters student excellence through her focus on real-world skills, challenges her students to become scientists and wants them to understand that learning is a collaborative effort.

As the winner of the district-level Teacher of the Year, Farrar is now eligible to compete at the regional and state level in the Missouri Teacher of the Year program, which is conducted annually by the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

An art assignment that Chesterfield Elementary fourth-grade student Jasmyn Callaham submitted last week has gained significant attention on social media.

Callaham recreated a contemporary piece by American painter Amy Sherald. Art teacher Julie Glossenger then decided to share the artwork to the classroom Instagram account.

"I asked Jaz's mom if it would be OK to post her work on our classroom Instagram and tag the artist, since she has an online presence," said Glossenger. "She approved so I put it up, hoping to catch a like from the artist, only to find that she was so taken with it, she reposted it!"

In the repost that has raked in more than 14,000 likes and 250 comments, Sherald commented, "Brilliantly executed!!" Callaham was thrilled when she heard the news.

"When my mom told me about the artist reposting my project, I was shocked," said Callaham. "I was excited that so many people liked it."

Read more: https://www.rsdmo.org/news/Pages/Chesterfield-Elementary-Student-Artwork-Recognized-by-Prominent-Painter.aspx

Rockwood Early Childhood Education speech-language pathologist Kim Gerth is one of 19 educators from around the country who have been selected for this year's PBS Digital Innovator All-Star Program.

Gerth was nominated by the Nine Network of Public Media for the program, which recognizes teachers doing extraordinary work in their local communities, supporting student learning by integrating media and digital technology in their teaching environments and inspiring students to use these tools in responsible, effective and empowering ways. Nine Network selected her as one of the channel's 10 Early Learning Champions last year.

Gerth, who works at Ballwin Elementary, is the only member of the PBS cohort who works in early childhood and is a special educator.

During the 2020-2021 school year, Gerth and the rest of the educators in the program will get the chance to deepen engagement among students, families, educators, schools and their local PBS stations.

Read more: https://www.rsdmo.org/news/Pages/Rockwood-Early-Childhood-Educator-Selected-as-PBS-Digital-Innovator-All-Star.aspx

Dr. Jessica Bergtholdt has been selected as the new interim assistant principal at Rockwood South Middle.

She begins her new position July 1 and is replacing Dr. Charity Schluter, who is taking a position outside the district.

Congratulations, Dr. Bergtholdt!

Rockwood administrators have decided to reopen school district athletic tracks, which were closed March 27 to help mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

Rockwood Chief Financial Officer Paul Northington said administrators temporarily limited access to the tracks out of concern for public safety. Too many people were gathering in groups on the tracks during the COVID-19 pandemic.

"We realize a lot of people utilize those tracks for exercise," said Northington. "If they can maintain social distancing and avoid gathering in groups, we can keep them open."

This only applies to athletic tracks, not other outdoor district facilities such as football fields, tennis courts and playgrounds.

"We need to observe our surroundings," said Rockwood Superintendent Dr. Mark Miles. "Athletic fields are no different just because they are outdoors. If people can practice social distancing and limit close contact, we can leave the tracks open."

The Rockwood School District Board of Education held its reorganization meeting Thursday, April 16, via a Zoom video conference.

Directors Dr. Keith Kinder, Lynne Midyett and Randy Miller were all sworn in for new three-year terms that will end in the spring of 2023. Kinder has been on the board since 2011, Midyett since 2016 and Miller since 2017. Midyett has served as the board vice president for the 2019-2020 school year.

The board also decided on its executive team for the 2020-2021 school year, re-electing Loralee Mondl president, Midyett vice president, Administrative Assistant to the Superintendent Janet Sadowski secretary and Chief Financial Officer Paul Northington treasurer.

"I have had the distinct pleasure of working with these seven outstanding board members for the past 10 months, and I look forward to continuing the collaboration we have shared and building upon the work we have done," said Superintendent Dr. Mark Miles.

The preschool classroom at Ballwin Elementary hosted a very special reunion on Friday, Feb. 28. More than 20 former students of Early Childhood teacher Cindy Crites, who has taught at Ballwin for the past 14 years, gathered to snack on applesauce and donuts and share some memories.

The students ranged from kindergarten through fifth grade.

“The kids were asking, ‘Do you remember what spot was mine? Where do I sit?’” Crites said, with a laugh. “It was emotional. The parents were coming in and hugging me and thanking me for doing this. It feels like yesterday that the kids were here.”

Crites said some of the students’ favorite memories included cookies around the holidays, scavenger hunts in the school and playing pretend at stations around the classroom.

Teaching in the same room for so long has given Crites the opportunity to see class after class grow up and move on from Ballwin. Last year, she had her first graduating seniors come back and pay her a visit.

“Once they’re my kids, they’re always my kids,” Crites said. “No matter how old they are.”

All grade levels at Crestview Middle took part in a Black History Month breakout box activity during mentor time on Monday, Feb. 24.

The students learned about the lives of such influential African-Americans as Sarah Goode, Thurgood Marshall, Jesse Owens and Sojourner Truth, then split into groups and deciphered clues about each historical figure to unlock their box and "break out."

The activity was part of a schedule of events planned by a group of Crestview eighth-graders to commemorate Black History Month. They also highlighted influential African-Americans on the morning announcements throughout the month, made posters to hang around the school and presented to classes on important historical figures.

"We talk about how black history is not just a month, it’s something we celebrate all year long," said eighth-grade social studies teacher Meghan Menchella. "This group has been student-led and has really just taken a life of its own."

The ROSE Award honors the best of Rockwood. Nearly 210 nominations were submitted with stories highlighting excellence of character, leadership, performance, and extraordinary service to Rockwood. Teachers, nurses, secretaries, custodians, parents, community members cover just some of the people who were nominated.

The ROSE Selection Committee is now in the process of selecting the 15 ROSE recipients.

In early March, ROSE committee chairs will visit ROSE Award recipients to surprise the honorees with one of the district's greatest recognitions.

The ROSE Award recipients will be honored on Sunday, May 3 -- along with Cornerstone, Teacher of the Year, Retirees and Service Award honorees.

Congratulations to all the nominees! Check out a complete list at https://www.rsdmo.org/news/Pages/Congratulations-2020-ROSE-Award-Nominees.aspx.

Rockwood School District honored students, staff and community members at the Board of Education awards ceremony at Eureka High School on Feb. 6.

School Board President Loralee Mondl began the ceremony with opening remarks, and Superintendent Dr. Mark Miles welcomed award recipients on stage. Board of Education directors Dr. Keith Kinder and Tom Dunn assisted Dr. Miles with the award presentations.

All four high schools were represented, along with a robotics team composed of elementary and middle school students.

"It's so good to be able to get together as a school community and celebrate our successes," said Dr. Miles to award recipients and their families. "We are honored to share this evening with you."

After the ceremony, a reception was held for all honored guests.

To see a gallery of photos from the ceremony, visit https://www.rsdmo.org/departments/boe/awards/Feb2020/Pages/default.aspx.

Cassandra Walker Suggs has been selected as the new assistant principal at Rockwood South Middle School.

Suggs has a Certificate of School Management and Leadership from Harvard University. She holds an Educational Specialist in Leadership and Policy Analysis certificate from the University of Missouri. Suggs currently serves as a dean of students for Hickman High School and prior to that served as an assistant principal-intern and teacher in Washington School District. For more than 20 years, Suggs has also worked as an author and television host. Her adolescent self-esteem books have been used in colleges and grade schools. Suggs has also been an adjunct professor at University of Missouri School of Journalism.

Suggs begins July 1 replacing Kara Welty, who is taking a position outside the district.

Dr. Corey Sink has been selected as the new principal at Eureka High School.

A Eureka resident, Sink is currently assistant principal at Parkway West High School. Prior to that, Sink served as assistant principal at Parkway South High School. He also served as an assistant principal and marketing and business education teacher in the St. Charles School District.

Sink earned his Doctorate of Education and Master's in Education Administration degrees at Lindenwood University.

At both Parkway West and Parkway South, Sink led building-wide professional learning opportunities.

Dr. Sink begins July 1 and is replacing Charlie Crouther, who is retiring.

How many inclement weather, or "snow" days does Rockwood have left on the calendar before we need to start making up days?

Missouri law requires school districts to count hours in school instead of days. As of Jan. 29, Rockwood has missed the equivalent of five school days due to inclement weather this school year.

The 2019-2020 Rockwood School Board-approved calendar allows six snow days before we start making up days. That means we have one more snow day available before we start making up days.

Rockwood Assistant Superintendent Human Resources Dr. Katie Reboulet said, "We're choosing this, as a district, because we believe in our teachers' instructional time."

With the cancellation of the seventh day of school, Rockwood would start adding days to the calendar, which currently lists May 21 as the last day of school for students. (For seniors, that day is May 15.)
